title: Hanging block and block on frictionless table

content.question: Block <math alttext="A," overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of mass <math alttext="m sub A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is on a horizontal table of negligible friction. A light string is attached to block <math alttext="A," overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, extends over an ideal pulley, and is attached to block <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of mass <math alttext="m sub B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, which is hanging off the table, as shown in the figure. When the blocks are held at rest, the tension in the string is <math alttext="T equals, m sub B, times g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>T</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></msub><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> . The blocks are then released from rest. Which of the following is a correct expression for the new tension in the string while both blocks are moving?
